messages.content: Explain me streams in java with examples

Streams in Java are classes which allow for a sequence of data elements to be processed. They are often used when working with large datasets as they can be used to efficiently process a large number of elements in a single operation. For example, a stream may be used to read a large file and process each line of the file one at a time. Another example is a stream which is used to process a large dataset in a database. The stream would allow for each record in the database to be processed in a single operation without having to iterate through the entire dataset.
Is streams are always more eficient than regular way?

No, streams are not always more efficient than the regular way. In some cases, it may be more efficient to use the regular way as it allows more flexibility in how the data is processed. However, in most cases, streams are more efficient as they allow for a single operation to be performed on a large dataset, rather than having to iterate through each element individually.
